unnormalised: **Environmental Concerns Mount as Air Quality Dips in Several Indian Cities**
normalised: **Environmental Concerns Mount as Air Quality Dips in Several Indian Cities**

unnormalised: New Delhi – Air quality across several Indian cities has deteriorated significantly, raising concerns among environmentalists and public health officials. The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) recorded an Air Quality Index (AQI) exceeding 300 in Delhi-NCR, categorizing it as “very poor.” Similar trends were observed in Kolkata and Mumbai, with particulate matter (PM2.5) levels well above permissible limits.
normalised: New Delhi – Air quality across several Indian cities has deteriorated significantly, raising concerns among environmentalists and public health officials. The Central Pollution Control Board (C P C B) recorded an Air Quality Index (A Q I) exceeding three hundred in Delhi-N C R, categorizing it as “very poor.” Similar trends were observed in Kolkata and Mumbai, with particulate matter (P M two point five) levels well above permissible limits.

unnormalised: Experts attribute the decline to a combination of factors, including vehicular emissions, industrial activities, and stubble burning in neighboring states, particularly Punjab and Haryana. The approaching Diwali festival, with its associated firecrackers, is expected to further exacerbate the situation.
normalised: Experts attribute the decline to a combination of factors, including vehicular emissions, industrial activities, and stubble burning in neighboring states, particularly Punjab and Haryana. The approaching Diwali festival, with its associated firecrackers, is expected to further exacerbate the situation.

unnormalised: Dr. Sharma from the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) cautioned about the increased risk of respiratory ailments, especially among children and the elderly. The government has urged citizens to take necessary precautions and encouraged the use of public transport. Discussions are also underway to explore alternative solutions, like cloud seeding, to mitigate the pollution. This spike coincides with the festivities surrounding Onam in Kerala, raising concerns about the impact on outdoor celebrations and the preparation of traditional feasts like Onam Sadhya. Rs. 20 crores have been allocated for implementing anti-pollution measures in highly affected zones.
